Objective.evidence: OBJECTIVES: To conduct an integrative synthesis of: effectiveness of behaviour change technique-based interventions on daily physical activity and clinical-/patient-reported outcomes; behaviour change techniques and theoretical mechanisms within effective behaviour change technique-based interventions; feasibility and acceptability.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Primary outcomes: short term (< 6 months) and maintenance (> 6 months) of daily physical activity.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Eleven randomised controlled trials demonstrated that behaviour change technique-based interventions increased daily physical activity in the short term [increase of 0.20 standardised mean difference (95% confidence interval 0.07 to 0.33), ~ 473 steps/day] with high certainty.

Trial_Registration.evidence: STUDY REGISTRATION: This study is registered as PROSPERO CRD42020159869.

Funding.evidence: FUNDING: This award was funded by the National Institute for Health and Care Research (NIHR) Health Technology Assessment programme (NIHR award ref: NIHR130664) and is published in full in Health Technology Assessment; Vol. 29, No. 18.
